title: JavaControlFlow - Q0001
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which keyword is used to start a conditional statement in Java?
explanation: The 'if' keyword is used to start a conditional statement.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0002
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which keyword is used to provide an alternative condition in an if statement?
explanation: The 'else' keyword provides an alternative block when the if condition is false.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0003
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which keyword is used to test multiple conditions in sequence?
explanation: The 'else if' statement allows testing multiple conditions in sequence.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0004
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to execute one block of code among many options?
explanation: The 'switch' statement executes one block of code among many options.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0005
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which keyword is used inside a switch statement to specify a condition?
explanation: The 'case' keyword specifies a condition inside a switch statement.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0006
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which keyword is used to exit a switch statement?
explanation: The 'break' statement exits a switch or loop.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0007
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which keyword is used to provide a default case in a switch statement?
explanation: The 'default' keyword specifies the block to execute if no case matches.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0008
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which loop executes a block of code a fixed number of times?
explanation: The 'for' loop executes a block of code a fixed number of times.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0009
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which loop checks the condition before executing the block?
explanation: The 'while' loop checks the condition before executing the block.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0010
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which loop executes the block at least once?
explanation: The 'do-while' loop executes the block at least once before checking the condition.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0011
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to skip the current iteration of a loop?
explanation: The 'continue' statement skips the current iteration and moves to the next.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0012
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to terminate a loop immediately?
explanation: The 'break' statement terminates a loop immediately.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0013
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which keyword is used to return a value from a method?
explanation: The 'return' keyword returns a value from a method.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0014
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which control statement is used to handle exceptions?
explanation: The 'try-catch' block is used to handle exceptions.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0015
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which block always executes after try-catch?
explanation: The 'finally' block always executes after try-catch, regardless of exceptions.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0016
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to throw an exception manually?
explanation: The 'throw' keyword is used to manually throw an exception.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0017
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which keyword is used in a method signature to declare exceptions?
explanation: The 'throws' keyword declares exceptions that a method can throw.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0018
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which loop is best suited when the number of iterations is known?
explanation: The 'for' loop is best when the number of iterations is known.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0019
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which loop is best suited when the number of iterations is unknown?
explanation: The 'while' loop is used when the number of iterations is unknown.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0020
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which loop guarantees at least one execution of the loop body?
explanation: The 'do-while' loop executes the body at least once before checking the condition.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0021
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to exit from multiple nested loops at once?
explanation: A labeled break statement can exit multiple nested loops.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0022
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement transfers control to the next iteration of the labeled loop?
explanation: A labeled continue statement skips to the next iteration of the labeled loop.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0023
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] What will happen if the condition in a while loop is always true?
explanation: If the condition is always true, the loop runs infinitely.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0024
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which of the following is a valid for loop syntax?
explanation: The correct syntax is for(initialization; condition; increment).

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0025
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which of the following is a valid while loop syntax?
explanation: The condition in a while loop must be enclosed in parentheses.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0026
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which of the following is a valid do-while loop syntax?
explanation: The correct syntax is do { } while (condition);

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0027
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to terminate the program execution?
explanation: System.exit(0) terminates the program execution.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0028
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which of the following is true about the switch statement?

options.text: It can evaluate byte, short, int, char, String, and enum types

explanation: Switch supports byte, short, int, char, String, and enum types.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0029
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] What happens if break is omitted in a switch case?
explanation: Without break, execution falls through to subsequent cases.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0030
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to handle multiple exceptions?
explanation: Multiple catch blocks can handle different exceptions.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0031
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to rethrow an exception?
explanation: The 'throw' keyword can rethrow an exception.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0032
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to execute code regardless of exceptions?
explanation: The 'finally' block executes regardless of exceptions.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0033
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which loop is used to iterate over arrays or collections?
explanation: The for-each loop iterates over arrays or collections.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0034
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which of the following is a valid for-each loop syntax?
explanation: The correct syntax is for (type variable : collection).

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0035
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] What is the output of the following code? int x = 5; if (x > 10) System.out.println("A"); else System.out.println("B");
explanation: Since x is not greater than 10, 'B' is printed.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0036
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] What is the output of the following code? int x = 10; while (x < 10) { x++; } System.out.println(x);
explanation: The condition is false initially, so x remains 10.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0037
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] What is the output of the following code? int x = 0; do { x++; } while (x < 3); System.out.println(x);
explanation: The loop runs three times, incrementing x to 3.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0038
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] What is the output of the following code? for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) { if (i == 1) continue; System.out.print(i); }
explanation: When i == 1, continue skips printing, so output is 02.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0039
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] What is the output of the following code? for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) { if (i == 1) break; System.out.print(i); }
explanation: The loop breaks when i == 1, so only 0 is printed.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0040
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to handle multiple conditions more efficiently than if-else?
explanation: The switch statement handles multiple conditions efficiently.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0041
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement can be used to exit from a method early?
explanation: The return statement exits from a method early.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0042
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to handle exceptions that may occur in a block of code?
explanation: The try block contains code that may throw exceptions.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0043
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to handle the exception thrown by a try block?
explanation: The catch block handles exceptions thrown by the try block.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0044
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement ensures that a block of code executes regardless of exceptions?
explanation: The finally block executes regardless of exceptions.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0045
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to handle multiple exceptions in a single catch block?
explanation: Multiple exceptions can be handled using the '|' operator in a single catch block.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0046
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to rethrow an exception after handling it?
explanation: The throw statement can rethrow an exception after handling.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0047
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to define a block of code that must execute after try-catch?
explanation: The finally block defines code that must execute after try-catch.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0048
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to handle specific types of exceptions?
explanation: The catch block handles specific types of exceptions.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0049
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to define a block of code that may throw exceptions?
explanation: The try block defines code that may throw exceptions.

title: JavaControlFlow - Q0050
text: [Java Basics - Control Flow] Which statement is used to handle multiple conditions compactly?
explanation: The ternary operator (condition ? value1 : value2) handles conditions compactly.
